ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course, which explores how different forms of speculation, from speculative fiction to speculative design to worldbuilding, really forced me to stretch my imagination and to reconsider my understanding of some of the basic methodological presuppositions of social science research. So much of what animated this course was a sense that our current way of construing the relationship between the study of empirical reality and projects of social change need to be inverted: speculation, perhaps, can help us find a way out of the many intersecting crises that exist in the present moment.
Animation, rapid worldbuilding, story sharing in classroom settings.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
This course was pretty experimental (by design), and so it was inevitably going to be a bit rough around the edges. The first half considered different forms of speculation, while the second half was an extended group exercise. I think that specific weeks of the first half of the course will appeal to different people based on the interests they are coming in with: given my academic background, I was much more interested in the week on speculative fiction, for example, than I was on the week on speculative design. 

I think the biggest way the course could be improved is by rethinking the second half creative project. Ours ended up being quite improvisatory, as we (including Professor Messeri) collectively decided we didn't want to take part in the project that Professor Messeri included on the original syllabus. So I think that ideally the course could formalize a more specific version of what the creative project looks like.

incredible course concept. Prof Messeri really expanded what I thought a class could be like. I think finding clearer parameters for the collective world building would have helped a lot. Constraints help my creativity a lot more than open freedom.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)

Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to another student who 1) feels a latent dissatisfaction with the forms of knowledge production that pervade the university and who feels frustrated at how insulated the university can feel from the core social and political issues of our time, 2) can tolerate a lot of ambiguity and is willing to take risks with their own thinking and writing, and 3) enjoys working with and learning from other people  this class relies A LOT on cooperation and collaboration, which is part of what makes it great.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
